alert.note: Alert for Delaware (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 9:29PM EST until January 10 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Pennsylvania... Chester Creek Near Chester affecting Delaware County. For the Chester Creek...including Chester...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Chester Creek near Chester. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, The creek floods adjacent open land. At 10.5 feet, Flood damage, adjacent to the creek, begins in the city of Chester. At 11.5 feet, Parker and Kerlin Streets flood. The 600 to 1300 blocks of Parker Street are subject to evacuations. The 1300-1400 blocks of Kerlin Street are also subject to evacuations. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:16 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 10.1 feet and rising. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:16 PM EST Tuesday was 10.1 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 11.1 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight to 2.4 feet and begin rising again late tomorrow evening. It will rise above flood stage late tomorrow evening and continue to rise to 9.2 feet early Thursday morning. It will then fall again but remain above flood stage. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 11.2 feet on 01/19/1996. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Stream Fld Observed Fcsts (9 pm) Crest Location Stg Stg Day/Time Wed Thu Stg Time Date Chester Creek Chester 8.0 10.1 Tue 9 pm 2.5 MSG 11.1 11pm 1/09 &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Turn around...don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/phi. The next statement will be issued Wednesday morning at 900 AM EST.
